title: News Archive
text:
December
2024
Article: "Counting on Justice: Bridging Quantitative Research and Community Empowerment" is published in MAA Focus.


September
2024
In the fall of 2024, I was on sabbatical!


July
2024
I wrote a blog post for Math Values: "Quantitative Justice: Using Data Science for Good".



Article: "Data Collection and Analysis for Small-Town Policing: Challenges and Recommendations" is published in Statistics and Public Policy.



I organize the Human Networks, Social Sciences, and Economics track at SciPy 2024.



I am invited to present in the Workshop Celebrating Diversity Minisymposium: Quantitative Justice through Applied Data Science at the SIAM Annual Meeting in Spokane, WA.


May
2024
Seattle University is set to host the annual conference for Women In Data Science Puget Sound.


March
2024
I am accompanying John Carter to co-lead a student experience in Chile for a course entitled Mathematical Models of Wave-Energy Extraction.


February
2024
I serve as a mentor in An Evening of Mentorship with Women In Data Science Puget Sound.


January
2024
I give a talk in the NAM-SIAM Special Session on Quantitative Justice at the Joint Mathematics Meetings in San Francisco .


November
2023
I lead a team in the 2023 QSIDE Datathon4Justice, where we analyze policing data.


September
2023
Article: "Data Science and Social Justice in the Mathematics Community" is published in the Notices of the American Mathematical Society.


August
2023
Preprint: I am a co-author on a new preprint, Small-Town Police Accountability: Challenges and Recommendations.


July
2023
I give a talk at SciPy: Scientific Computing with Python in Austin, TX.



I am a participant in the Educating at the Intersection of Data Science and Social Justice workshop at the Institute for Computational and Experimental Research in Mathematics (ICERM).


March
2023
Preprint: I am a joint author on overview article on "Data science and social justice in the mathematics community." The team is Quindel Jones, Andrés R. Vindas Meléndez, myself, Manuchehr Aminian, Heather Zinn Brooks, Nathan Alexander, Carrie Diaz Eaton, and Phil Chodrow.


January
2023
I attend the Joint Mathematics Meetings in Boston, MA.


November
2022
I lead a team in the 2022 QSIDE Datathon4Justice, where we work on cleaning and analyzing policing data.


September
2022
Article: I contribute to the COMAP (Consortium for Mathematics and its Applications) Newsletter with an article entitled Getting Away from One Right Answer.


July
2022
I participate in the Data Science and Social Justice: Networks, Policy, and Education summer workshop at ICERM.


April
2022
I give a virtual talk with Manuch Aminian about the SToPA Lab's progress at the 2022 QSIDE Data4Justice Conference [recording].


November
2021
Work from the Datathon4Justice grows roots as a permanent research group, the Small Town Police Accountability (SToPA) Research Lab. I co-lead this lab with Anna Haensch and Manuchehr Aminian.


October
2021
I co-lead a team in the QSIDE Datathon4Justice with Dr. Anna Haensch. Our team works to read in police call logs from a small town.


August
2021
I join Seattle University as an assistant professor of Mathematics. I'll be supporting the new MS Data Science program.


July
2021
I participate in the 2021-2022 cohort of Project NExT (New Experiences in Teaching) through the Mathematical Association of America.

title: Teaching
text:
I teach a mix of data science and math courses Seattle University– my main emphasis is in the MS Data Science program. In all my classes, I place a strong emphasis on critical thinking, applying knowledge to real-world problems, and communication skills. I wrote an article in COMAP’s GAIMME Time (Guidelines for Assessment and Instruction in Mathematical Modeling Education) column about these goals.
If you teach similar courses and would like to share resources and ideas, please get in touch!

Courses

DATA 5322: Statistical Machine Learning II
DATA 5901 & 5902: MSDS Capstone series
DATA 3310 & 5310: Data Visualization
MATH 1335: Calculus II (Integral Calculus)



Teaching Resources

QSIDE Data4Justice Curriculum
Curriculum for data visualization using Altair, Python’s grammar of graphics plotting package
An Introduction to Statistical Learning by James, Witten, Hastie and Tibshirani, a texbook for machine learning, available in R and Python
The Craft of Community Engaged Teaching and Learning by Marshall Welch and Star Plaxton-Moore
Laziness Does Not Exist by Devon Price, blog post and full book

title: Research
text:
Reduced-Order Modeling
Spatiotemporal dynamical systems are ubiquitous across all areas of science and engineering. While some systems of interest can be studied through first-principles governing equations, often, the underlying dynamics are unknown. Furthermore, even for problems where equations are known, analytical solutions are rare. Computational solutions are then plagued by issues of nonlinearity, multiple relevant scales of time and space, chaos, and high-dimensionality. When parametric studies are needed, these simulations become prohibitively expensive, even under the most advance computational architectures.














Data-driven modeling of rotating detonation waves
Ariana Mendible, James Koch, Henning Lange, Steven L. Brunton, and and J. Nathan Kutz
Physical Review Fluids (2021)













Data-driven modeling of two-dimensional detonation wave fronts
Ariana Mendible, Weston Lowrie, Steven L. Brunton, and J. Nathan Kutz
Wave Motion (2022)













Dimensionality reduction and reduced-order modeling for traveling wave physics
Ariana Mendible, Steven L. Brunton, Aleksandr Y. Aravkin, and Wes Lowrie & J. Nathan Kutz
Theoretical and Computational Fluid Dynamics (2020)













Randomized nonnegative matrix factorization
N. Benjamin Erichson, Ariana Mendible, Sophie Wihlborn, and J. Nathan Kutz
Pattern Recognition Letters (2018)

title: Ariana Mendible
text:
Bio
I am an Assistant Professor of Mathematics at Seattle University, where I teach in our MS Data Science program and do research in quantitative justice. I co-lead the Data Science, Police Accountability, and Community Engagement (DSPACE) Research Lab. Our aim is to democratize access to publicly available data on policing. I received my PhD in Mechanical Engineering from the University of Washington, where I worked on reduced-order modeling for fluids systems with Steve Brunton and J Nathan Kutz.
